data.title: Holiday season overflowing with myriad movie openings
data.meta_description: Here's a list of tentative holiday movie release dates.
data.text:
Here's a list of tentative holiday movie release dates.

NOVEMBER 21

BLACK KNIGHT — Mark Twain's much-filmed (in various forms) fantasy tale "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court" gets an urban spin, as Martin Lawrence plays the modern man sent back in time to a medieval kingdom. Directed by Gil Junger ("10 Things I Hate About You").

OUT COLD — Snowboard action punctuates this romantic comedy about a boarder (Jason London) who tries to open a winter park to impress his ex-girlfriend (A.J. Cook, of "The Virgin Suicides").

SPY GAME — Robert Redford and Redford-for-the-New-Millennium Brad Pitt team up for this tale of international intrigue, shot in several European locations. Directed by Tony Scott ("Enemy of the State").

NOVEMBER 23

INNOCENCE — Australian filmmaker Paul Cox directed this drama about former lovers who decide to rekindle their relationship, heedless of the consequences for her marriage. In English and French, with English subtitles.

NOVEMBER 30

BEHIND ENEMY LINES — Comic actor Owen Wilson plays it straight in this military thriller about a U.S. Navy pilot shot down in enemy territory. Gene Hackman co-stars as his commanding officer who tries to rescue him.

THE MAN WHO WASN'T THERE — Co-winner of the Best Director award from the Cannes Film Festival, the latest from the Coen brothers is a noir thriller about a barber (Billy Bob Thornton) blackmailing his wife's lover. In black and white.

TEXAS RANGERS — Long-delayed Western adventure starring Dylan McDermott (TV's "The Practice") as the founder of the legendary lawmen. The young all-star cast also includes James Van Der Beek and Rachael Leigh Cook.

DECEMBER 7

OCEAN'S 11 — All-star remake of the 1960 Rat Pack heist thriller, directed by Steven Soderbergh. The cast includes George Clooney, Julia Roberts, Matt Damon, Brad Pitt and Andy Garcia.

DECEMBER 14

NOT ANOTHER TEEN MOVIE — Sendup of the glut of teen-oriented films, featuring spoofs of "Bring It On," "Cruel Intentions" and "The Breakfast Club." Jaime Pressly, Chyler Leigh and Deon Richmond star.

THE OTHER SIDE OF HEAVEN — Young actors Christopher Gorham and Anne Hathaway ("The Princess Diaries") star in this drama, based on the harrowing real-life experiences of an LDS general authority when he was a teenager serving a mission to the Kingdom of Tonga.

VANILLA SKY — Tom Cruise stars in director Cameron Crowe's enigmatic romantic fantasy. The supporting cast includes Cameron Diaz, Kurt Russell and Cruise's new off-screen interest, Penelope Cruz.

DECEMBER 19

THE LORD OF THE RINGS: THE FELLOWSHIP OF THE RING — New Zealand director Peter Jackson adapts the first of the much-read fantasy trilogy, with state-of-the-art effects and an all-star cast that includes Elijah Wood, Sir Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler and Christopher Lee.

DECEMBER 21

JIMMY NEUTRON: BOY GENIUS — Digitally animated comedy about the title character, a whiz-kid who may be the last line of defense against alien invaders. Among those providing voices are Martin Short and Patrick Stewart.

JOE SOMEBODY — The title character of this comedy-drama is a picked-on man (Tim Allen) who decides to fight back after being bullied on Bring Your Daughter to Work Day. Jim Belushi and Julie Bowen (TV's "Ed") co-star.

KATE & LEOPOLD — Meg Ryan and Hugh Jackman star as the title characters, seemingly star-crossed lovers, in this time-traveling romantic comedy written and directed by James Mangold ("Girl, Interrupted").

THE MAJESTIC — Capra-esque fable from filmmaker Frank Darabont, starring Jim Carrey as a blacklisted Hollywood writer who "reinvents" himself as a theater owner after a car wreck causes him to lose his memory.

DECEMBER 25

ALI — Will Smith "transformed" himself to play the legendary prize fighter in this biographical drama from director Michael Mann. Jamie Foxx, Jon Voight and Mario Van Peebles co-star.

A BEAUTIFUL MIND — Drama based on the true-life story of paranoid schizophrenic John Forbes Nash Jr., with Russell Crowe starring as the troubled, Nobel Prize-winning mathematician. Ron Howard directs.

IMPOSTOR — Science-fiction thriller from director Gary Fleder ("Kiss the Girls"), starring Gary Sinise as a futuristic scientist who becomes Public Enemy No. 1 overnight when he's accused of being a renegade android.

THE SHIPPING NEWS — Director Lasse Hallstrom adapts the best-selling novel about a middle-aged man (Kevin Spacey) who relocates his family to Newfoundland after having a nervous breakdown. Julianne Moore co-stars.

DECEMBER 26

HOW HIGH — Rappers-turned-actors Redman and Method Man star in this drug-culture comedy about two stoners whose intelligence is increased dramatically by the genetically altered drug they've been smoking.

SCHEDULED TO OPEN BUT WITHOUT FIRM DATES

ABERDEEN — Described as a "dark road movie," this drama stars Lena Headey ("Gossip") as a young woman charged with bringing her alcoholic father (Stellan Skarsgard) to see his wife before she dies.

THE ACCIDENTAL SPY — Jackie Chan goes it alone again in this action-comedy about an exercise equipment salesman who finds himself on the run after he's mistakenly identified as a secret agent. Dubbed.

THE AFFAIR OF THE NECKLACE — Based on real-life events that may have helped start the French Revolution, this historical drama stars Hilary Swank as a young woman who, stripped of her royal heritage, hatches a revenge scheme.

BLACK HAWK DOWN — Up-and-coming actors Josh Hartnett and Eric Bana star in director Ridley Scott's military thriller, based on a real-life incidents, about paratroopers dropped into a Somalian war zone.

CHARLOTTE GRAY — Cate Blanchett stars in this World War II drama as the title character, a Scottish woman trying to rescue her pilot boyfriend, who is lost behind enemy lines. Billy Crudup co-stars.

GOSFORD PARK — Robert Altman directed this period piece about the class differences between the guests and servants of a guest house in London. Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and Ryan Phillippe star.

GRATEFUL DAWG — Documentary from filmmaker Gillian Grisman, examining the friendship between her father, bluegrass musician David Grisman, and late Grateful Dead frontman Jerry Garcia.

IN THE BEDROOM — Ensemble drama from indie actor Todd Field. The cast includes Sissy Spacek, Marisa Tomei and Tom Wilkinson. A selection of the 2001 Sundance Film Festival.

THE ROYAL TENENBAUMS — Offbeat filmmaker Wes Anderson returns with this comedy about a family patriarch (Gene Hackman) striving to reconnect with his estranged children (including Gwyneth Paltrow and Ben Stiller).

SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK — Actor Edward Burns returns to filmmaking with this ensemble drama about the lives and loves of several New Yorkers. The cast includes Heather Graham, Stanley Tucci and Dennis Farina.
